member.name: M:CryEngine.Collision.RayIntersectsPoint(CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Vec3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a point.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Collision.RayIntersectsRay(CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Vec3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method performs a ray vs ray intersection test based on the following formula from Goldman. s = det([o_2 - o_1, d_2, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 t = det([o_2 - o_1, d_1, d_1 x d_2]) / ||d_1 x d_2||^2 Where o_1 is the position of the first ray, o_2 is the position of the second ray, d_1 is the normalized direction of the first ray, d_2 is the normalized direction of the second ray, det denotes the determinant of a matrix, x denotes the cross product, [ ] denotes a matrix, and || || denotes the length or magnitude of a vector.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Collision.RayIntersectsPlane(CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Plane@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Collision.RayIntersectsPlane(CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Plane@,CryEngine.Vec3@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a .
member.param: When the method completes, contains the point of intersection, or if there was no intersection.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Collision.RayIntersectsTriangle(CryEngine.Ray@,CryEngine.Vec3@,CryEngine.Vec3@,CryEngine.Vec3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Determines whether there is an intersection between a and a triangle.
member.param: The first vertex of the triangle to test.
The second vertex of the triagnle to test.
The third vertex of the triangle to test.
When the method completes, contains the distance of the intersection, or 0 if there was no intersection.
member.remarks: This method tests if the ray intersects either the front or back of the triangle. If the ray is parallel to the triangle's plane, no intersection is assumed to have happened. If the intersection of the ray and the triangle is behind the origin of the ray, no intersection is assumed to have happened. In both cases of assumptions, this method returns false.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Matrix34.SetSlerp(CryEngine.Matrix34,CryEngine.Matrix34,System.Single)
member.summary: Direct-Matrix-Slerp: for the sake of completeness, I have included the following expression for Spherical-Linear-Interpolation without using quaternions. This is much faster then converting both matrices into quaternions in order to do a quaternion slerp and then converting the slerped quaternion back into a matrix. This is a high-precision calculation. Given two orthonormal 3x3 matrices this function calculates the shortest possible interpolation-path between the two rotations. The interpolation curve forms a great arc on the rotation sphere (geodesic). Not only does Slerp follow a great arc it follows the shortest great arc. Furthermore Slerp has constant angular velocity. All in all Slerp is the optimal interpolation curve between two rotations. STABILITY PROBLEM: There are two singularities at angle=0 and angle=PI. At 0 the interpolation-axis is arbitrary, which means any axis will produce the same result because we have no rotation. Thats why I'm using (1,0,0). At PI the rotations point away from each other and the interpolation-axis is unpredictable. In this case I'm also using the axis (1,0,0). If the angle is ~0 or ~PI, then we have to normalize a very small vector and this can cause numerical instability. The quaternion-slerp has exactly the same problems. Ivo

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec2.DistanceSquared(CryEngine.Vec2@,CryEngine.Vec2@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec2.Orthogonalize(CryEngine.Vec2[],CryEngine.Vec2[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec2.Orthonormalize(CryEngine.Vec2[],CryEngine.Vec2[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec4.DistanceSquared(CryEngine.Vec4@,CryEngine.Vec4@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec3.DistanceSquared(CryEngine.Vec3@,CryEngine.Vec3@,System.Single@)
member.summary: Calculates the squared distance between two vectors.
member.param: When the method completes, contains the squared distance between the two vectors.
member.remarks: Distance squared is the value before taking the square root. Distance squared can often be used in place of distance if relative comparisons are being made. For example, consider three points A, B, and C. To determine whether B or C is further from A, compare the distance between A and B to the distance between A and C. Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

Calculating the two distances involves two square roots, which are computationally expensive. However, using distance squared provides the same information and avoids calculating two square roots.

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec3.Orthogonalize(CryEngine.Vec3[],CryEngine.Vec3[])
member.summary: Orthogonalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthogonalize.

remarks.para: Orthogonalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other. This means that any given vector in the list will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .

member.name: M:CryEngine.Vec3.Orthonormalize(CryEngine.Vec3[],CryEngine.Vec3[])
member.summary: Orthonormalizes a list of vectors.
member.param: The list of vectors to orthonormalize.

remarks.para: Orthonormalization is the process of making all vectors orthogonal to each other and making all vectors of unit length. This means that any given vector will be orthogonal to any other given vector in the list.

Because this method uses the modified Gram-Schmidt process, the resulting vectors tend to be numerically unstable. The numeric stability decreases according to the vectors position in the list so that the first vector is the most stable and the last vector is the least stable.

member.exception: Thrown when or is null.
Thrown when is shorter in length than .
